{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3676512,"name":"Dean","username":"dean75","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/c67d28/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-08T12:49:34.147Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone! I have tried to use the CAN protocol for two different projects now and I cannot seem to send CAN messages from the devices but both times I was able to receive messages. In my first project I used a PCAN-USB connected to a murr 55760 CANOpen device with a hydraulic servo controller at the other end that uses the CANOpen protocol. I was able to receive a heartbeat from the servo controller but I was not able to move the servo. When I used a app instead of CANOpen the servo worked just fine and it came pre-tested and pre-wired from the factory so there shouldnâ€™t have been any problems. In my second project I used a roboteq on Extended RawCAN mode connected to a Sun XMD-01 hydraulic controller. The Sun XMD-01 does use the J1939 CAN protocol so maybe there is something I am missing there but I am able to receive messages from the XMD to the roboteq showing some faults. I am not that familiar with CAN protocols so maybe there is something in both of these projects I am missing. Any help with this is appreciated. Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-07-08T14:26:45.410Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":128.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504042,"topic_slug":"need-help-with-can","display_username":"Dean","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71825,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/need-help-with-can/504042/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3676580,"name":"Chadfrom7226","username":"Chadfrom7226","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadfrom7226/{size}/113429_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-08T15:13:53.653Z","cooked":"

For the first one, Iâ€™m not sure 100% about how the CANopen protocol works, but python has a library and works with PCAN adapters

https://canopen.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

For the second one, make sure your data rates are correct. FRC devices use 1mbps CAN, automotive uses 500kbps, and heavy duty trucks use 250kbps

Make sure youâ€™re using the right data rates.

J1939 typically is 250kbps and uses extended IDs often so make sure both of those are compatible

I set both devices to use 1mbps and the roboteq uses Extended RawCAN for the extended IDâ€™s. For the first project, I was trying just to use the PCAN-View app to made sure it worked before I used any APIâ€™s

Data speaked on CAN bus are not standardized. Which means both the controller and device being controlled. Needs to know each otherâ€™s protocol. So yes you have to understand how the protocol work and create your control software based on it.

For FRC, the specification use extended ID in specialized format which means pretty much all non FRC CAN electronics wonâ€™t be compatible in our control system without some format conversion.

Iâ€™m not sure what you mean by the control scheme but for the first project I just wanted to be able to start and move the hydraulic servo from the PCAN-View app with CANOpen that the servo uses. For the second project I wanted to be able to send a CAN command from the roboteq to the XMD-01 but since the XMD uses CAN J1939 I wasnâ€™t sure how to do that
